title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Act is amended to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy. This information can be used by federal and state agencies for benefits administration, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use or disclosure. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to provide information on deceased individuals to federal and state agencies for benefits administration, with safeguards in place to protect against unauthorized use or disclosure. Agencies can cooperate with the Commissioner, including reimbursing for associated costs, as long as it does not conflict with the Commissioner's duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can provide information on deceased individuals to federal agencies for specific purposes, such as operating the Do Not Pay working system or ensuring proper payments under federal programs. This cooperation must not conflict with the Commissioner's duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments, tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. Similar arrangements can be made with states for the same purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments, tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. Similar arrangements can be made with states for the administration of benefit pension plans or retirement systems. The information must be protected from unauthorized use or disclosure for statistical purposes and research activities. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal and state agencies for various purposes, including ensuring proper payments, tax administration, debt collection, and crime prevention. Information must be protected for statistical purposes and research activities. Amendments to sections of the Social Security Act and the Internal Revenue Code are outlined. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code and the Social Security Act allow the Commissioner of Social Security to share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data maintained by non-Federal sources. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data maintained by non-Federal sources for use by Federal agencies. The review will assess accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability of the data. A comparison will be made to the death data distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. A report is due within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment, recommending whether to extend agency access to death data from the Commissioner of Social Security. SEC. 7 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 amends the Act to improve the use of death data by government agencies. The Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012, in SEC. 7, requires the Office of Management and Budget to issue guidance to agencies on accessing death databases for improved data matching within 6 months of enactment. The Office of Management and Budget must develop a plan within 1 year to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing death records electronically to the Federal Government. This plan may include recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant Federal agencies, will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to improve data matching on deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. Additionally, an annual report must be submitted within 1 year of the enactment of this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation of a plan to improve data matching on deceased individuals receiving federally funded benefits. The report will include recommendations required under subsection (a)(2) and definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA BY SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The plan aims to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration, including identifying errors in records of extremely elderly individuals still alive and improving procedures for correcting inaccurate information. The plan requires the Commissioner of Social Security to correct erroneous records, improve identification of living and deceased individuals, implement better procedures for error correction, use statistical analysis to estimate erroneous records, and make recommendations for legislation. The plan must be implemented within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
